#â€‹532 â€” November 19, 2024

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Mailpit: Go-Powered Email and SMTP Testing Tool â€” A small, fast, efficient and zero-dependency email testing tool and API for developers. It acts as an SMTP server to which mail can be sent and provides a Web interface to read the mails. And being written in Go, it can be compiled to a single binary and put on whichever server you like. GitHubÂ repo.

Ralph Slooten

GoLand 2024.3 Released â€” The popular (commercial) Go IDE gets its latest big update with multiline AI code completion, improved startup times for large projects, a way to look for cyclic imports, and a way to emulate a terminal in the outputÂ console.

Ruslan Akhmetzianov (JetBrains)

Run GitHub Actions Up to 2x Faster at Half theÂ Cost â€” Blacksmith runs your GitHub Actions substantially faster by running them on modern gaming CPUs. Integrating Blacksmith is a one-line code change. 100+ companies like Ashby, Superblocks, and Slope use Blacksmith to help developers merge codeÂ faster.

Blacksmith sponsor

Understanding Command Injection Vulnerabilities in Go â€” If youâ€™re calling out to system utilities from your code, there are some basic yet essential precautions you can take to avoid security issues, because you certainly donâ€™t want anyone being able to convince your server to run rm orÂ worse..

Liran Tal (Snyk)

â–¶Â Â Developing a Terminal App in Go with Bubble Tea â€” A well produced 50-minute screencast walking through the creation of a practical note-taking command line tool using Go and Charmâ€™s Bubble Tea and Lip Gloss for structure, views, andÂ styling.

Package Main

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ”¥ Pyroscope's Go Playground lets you run Go code and immediately see a flame graph forÂ it.

  • ğŸ§ On the latest episode of the Go Time podcast, Anchor's Wesley Beary spoke about the challenges that arose when his team built a production-ready CLI tool inÂ Go.

  • ğŸ¤ Brian Kernighan, co-author of The Go Programming Language, â–¶ï¸Â went on a podcast to discuss his new book Unix: A History and a Memoir and what it was like working at Bell Labs.

  • RIP to Thomas E. Kurtz, the inventor of the BASIC programming language, who has died aged 96. While not a direct influence on Go, BASIC had a pivotal role in bringing programming to theÂ masses.

  • ğŸ¤– Ollama is a popular Go app for running large language models locally. It's just had a major revamp with the addition of lots of Go-powered image processing routines to support Llama 3.2 Vision for doing things like OCR and Q&A against suppliedÂ images.

Go sync.Once is Simple, But How Does It Work? â€” â€œThe sync.Once is probably the easiest sync primitive to use, but thereâ€™s more under the hood than you mightÂ think..â€

Phuong Le

Encountering Hyrum's Law in Go â€” When the author encountered an intriguing comment in Goâ€™s codebase warning others to not change some text due to â€œHyrumâ€™s Lawâ€, he had to find out what it was allÂ about.

Abenezer Belachew

ğŸ“„ Compiling a Go Program Into a Native Binary for Nintendo Switch â€“ Not new, but somehow I missed it at the time, but itâ€™s interesting to see theÂ details. Hajime Hoshi (Ebitengine)

ğŸ“„ The Go Module Proxy and Forcing Go to Actually Update Module Versions Chris Siebenmann

ğŸ“„ Migrating from Prisma to sqlc for Better Performance Alexander Belanger

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Signls: A Non-Linear, Generative MIDI Sequencer â€” If you like noodling with music, youâ€™ll enjoy this. Itâ€™s a Go-powered MIDI sequencer that runs in the terminal (cross-platform) and lets you create dynamic, generative music that evolves and changes over time. The author also created Sektron, a Go-powered MIDI step sequencer. GitHubÂ repo.

emprcl

WorkOS: Sell to Enterprises with a Few Lines of Code â€” The modern identity platform for B2B SaaS, offering flexible, easy-to-use APIs to integrate SSO, SCIM, and FGA in minutes instead ofÂ months.

WorkOS sponsor

Act: Run Your GitHub Actions Locally â€” Run act and it looks at your repoâ€™s GitHub Actions, uses Docker to grab the necessary images, and runs the tasksÂ locally.

Nektos

Git Town: Extra Commands for More Structured Git Usage â€” Provides additional git commands to automate the creation, synchronization, shipping, and cleanup of branches. Compatible with popular workflows, mono-repos, and trunk-based development. GitHubÂ repo.

Git Town Team

gosax: Libary for XML SAX (Simple API for XML) Parsing â€” A read-only XML parsing library focused on being â€˜efficient andÂ memory-conscious.â€™

Nao Yonashiro

  • Go Blueprint 0.9 â€“ Streamline the initialization of new GoÂ projects.

  • Listmonk 4.1 â€“ Self hosted email newsletterÂ system (homepage).

  • goshs 1.0 â€“ Imagine Python's SimpleHTTPServer but in Go.

  • html-to-markdown 2.2 â€“ Tool to convert HTML into cleanÂ Markdown.

  • validator 10.23 â€“ Value validations for structs and fields based onÂ tags.

  • ğŸ–¼ï¸ avif 0.4.2 â€“ AVIF image format encoder/decoder.

  • ğŸ–¼ï¸ jpegli 0.3.3 â€“ JPEG image format encoder/decoder.

  • Mockery 2.48 â€“ Generate mocks forÂ interfaces.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

ğŸ¤– Control RAG access with SpiceDB's fine-grained permissions in Go and openÂ source.

Hookdeck: An alternative to Amazon API Gateway + Lambda + SQS. With local dev, debugging, and observabilityÂ built-in.

item.title: ã€What's coming in Go 1.24ã€‘Go 1.24 ä¸­çš„æ–°åŠŸèƒ½
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹533 â€” November 26, 2024

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

GoMLX: ML in Go without Python â€” Eli recently wrote about Goâ€™s suitability as a glue language for calling out to third party machine learning services and Python â€˜sidecarsâ€™, but could you just do the heavy lifting from Go itself? GoMLX provides oneÂ option.

Eli Bendersky

ğŸ“Š Â What's Coming in Go 1.24 â€” A 52-slide deck that goes through language, tooling, and standard library changes coming to Go 1.24 (expected in January or February 2025). Thereâ€™s quite a bit here, including generic type aliases, weak pointers, and an experimental test package for concurrentÂ code.

Daniel MartÃ­

ğŸ’¡ You may remember â–¶ï¸ Daniel's similar talk about Go 1.22 a year ago â€“ when the video for the new talk lands, we'll link toÂ it.

Go! Unlock Your Tech Potential with Ardan Labs Consulting â€” Struggling with skill gaps, development speed or complex tech challenges? Ardan Labs specializes in Go, Rust, Docker and K8s to accelerate your software development, optimize architecture, and manage tech debt. Let us supercharge yourÂ team!

Ardan Labs Consulting sponsor

Are Go's Generics Simple or Incomplete? A Design Study â€” Some argue that Goâ€™s generic implementation only added complexity to the language, while others disagree. Nick takes us through a complex problem that he struggled to solve with generics, eventually ending up with a solution that works but felt a bit harder than necessary. Some commenters on Reddit felt that his approach was more OO / interface-based than it needed to be, though.

Nick Tobey (DoltHub)

â–¶Â Â WASI to Go: Write Once, Go Anywhere â€” A talk from the recent WASMCon event exploring Goâ€™s relationship with WebAssembly and how WASM can help â€˜Go go anywhere.â€™ A pretty good primer on the topic as things currentlyÂ stand.

Zhou and Reddig

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ–¼ï¸ Preslav Rachev's ebook Generative Art in Go is half-off thisÂ week.

  • Forget Go versus Rust, Go and Rust together make a great pair of languages to know, says John Arundel.

  • Matteo shows how a simple optimization sped up one of his dependencies "byÂ 38147125738.8x."

Inside Blueskyâ€™s Engineering Culture â€” A writeup from May 2024 thatâ€™s perhaps become more relevant with Blueskyâ€™s recent rapid ascent. Go sits at the heart of the social networkâ€™sÂ backend.

Gergely Orosz and Elin Nilsson

ğŸ“„ A Go Production Performance Gotcha with GOMAXPROCS â€“ A well understood but oft encountered gotcha when GOMAXPROCS isnâ€™tÂ set. Chris Battarbee

ğŸ“„ Investigating a Memory Leak with Pprof â€“ Commonly trod ground, but wellÂ explained. Aviv Zohari

ğŸ“„ Testing with Go and Postgres using Ephemeral DBs Michael Stapelberg

ğŸ“„ Getting a Pointer to a Constant in Go Xe Iaso

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

superfile: A Terminal-Based File Manager App â€” Built with Go and Bubble Tea, it combines a visually appealing design with the simplicity of terminal tools, providing a fresh, accessible approach to fileÂ management.

Yorukot

â™»ï¸Â recur: Retry a Command with Exponential Backoff and Jitter â€” A Go-powered command line tool for retrying shell based commands in a controlled way until a condition (or success) isÂ met.

D. Bohdan

WorkOS: Sell to Enterprises with a Few Lines of Code â€” The modern identity platform for B2B SaaS, offering flexible, easy-to-use APIs to integrate SSO, SCIM, and FGA in minutes instead ofÂ months.

WorkOS sponsor

Porcupine 1.0: A Fast Linearizability Checker â€” You write a spec for a system in Go, provide a concurrent history, and Porcupine figures out if the history is linearizable with respect to the spec. Thereâ€™s a 2017 blog post that explainsÂ more.

Anish Athalye

Sequin: Human-Readable ANSI Sequences â€” The latest work from the folks at Charm (well known for Bubble Tea, Lip Gloss and other libraries) interprets ANSI sequences into something you can actuallyÂ understand..

Charm

âš™ï¸ nats-mutex: Distributed Lock Library using NATS JetStream Yurii Biurher

  • ğŸ•’ Carbon 2.5 â€“ Developer friendly way to work with times and dates (examples).

  • Goose 3.23 â€“ Database migration tool. Supports SQL and GoÂ functions.

  • GoReleaser 2.4.8 â€“ Build/release binaries for multipleÂ platforms.

  • Mockery 2.49 â€“ Generate mock implementations ofÂ interfaces.

  • Ginkgo 2.22 â€“ Mature testingÂ framework.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

ğŸ“š Risk mitigation is key to safeguarding your organization's future. Discover how Temporal enhances reliability and minimizes risk inÂ finserv.

ğŸ¤– Control RAG access with SpiceDB's fine-grained permissions in Go and openÂ source.

ğŸ And a little bonus quote..

I saw this 2020 blog post by Brad Fitzpatrick the other day and liked an insight he shared about complexity and how Go changed his opinion of it:

"I used to tolerate and expect complexity. Working on Go the past 10 years has changed my perspective, though. I now value simplicity above almost all else and tolerate complexity only when it's well isolated, well documented, well tested, and necessary to make things simpler overall at other layers for most people."

___
Brad Fitzpatrick (Go team member 2010-2020)

ã€

#â€‹534 â€” December 3, 2024

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

The Draft Go 1.24 Release Notes â€” Last week, we enjoyed Daniel MartÃ­â€™s slidedeck on whatâ€™s coming in Go 1.24 early in 2025 â€“ weâ€™ve now noticed the draft release notes are coming along well and give a thorough bulletpoint-heavy roundup of what we canÂ expect.

Go Team

Weak Pointers in Go: Why They Matter Now â€” A look at a feature expected to land properly in Go 1.24 (via the weak package). Weak pointers are a low-level primitive that enable the creation of certain memory-efficient structures and Phuong explains the basics of how theyÂ work.

Phuong Le

We Put the Go in Google Gemini â€” Google Gemini 1.5 Flash 8B for Go has a 1M token context window, capable of processing more than 30,000 lines of code via screencast or logfiles in seconds for a fraction of the cost. Build today using the Google API Quickstart inÂ Go.

Google Gemini sponsor

Why Go Slices Still Surprise Me â€” Slices are a common source of confusion and bugs, and this could be due to the merging of two different use cases into one concept. Sometimes, itâ€™s a 'fat pointer'; sometimes, itâ€™s a dynamic array. Confusing the two is where the painÂ starts.

James Smith

Go-App: A Package to Build Progressive Web Apps with Go and WebAssembly â€” An intriguing way to build webapps entirely in Go (including the frontend UI). astextract is a Go-source-to-AST app that demonstrates the concept. GitHubÂ repo.

Maxence Charriere

Diving into eBPF: Building a Process Tracer from Scratch â€” This is certainly a deep dive down a technical Linux rabbit hole, but this sort of post is gold for when you need to plumb suchÂ depths.

The Smidt

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ¤ Lea Anthony of the Wails project went on go podcast() to discuss the art of building desktop apps using web tech. Wails is essentially a lighter weight Go-flavored take onÂ Electron.

  • GoReleaser is a popular tool for releasing Go binaries for numerous platforms at once, but it looks like both Rust and Zig support are on the way in the forthcomingÂ v2.5.

  • ğŸ„ If you fancy a daily programming challenge in the run up to Christmas, don't forget that the Advent of Code 2024 has begun.

Running a Simple Go Web Service on NixOS â€” â€œI only just started using NixOS modules to manage my personal services, but Iâ€™m excited at how well they work for so littleÂ investment.â€

Michael Lynch

ğŸ“„ Mastering Go Debugging from Emacs â€“ A lot of detail for fans of the long standing operating system editor. Victor Dorneanu

ğŸ“„ Lessons Learned Adding OpenTelemetry to a (Cobra) Command-Line Go Tool Jamie Tanna

ğŸ“„ The Smallest Thing in Go â€“ A quick look at Goâ€™s iota identifier. John Arundel

ğŸ“„ Good Union Types in Go Would Probably Need Types Without a Zero Value Chris Siebenmann

ğŸ“„ Building a Distributed Log using S3 (in Under 150 Lines of Go) Avinash Sajjanshetty

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Vince: Go-Powered, Self Hosted Web Analytics System â€” Web stats, link tracking, and more, for unlimited sites and in a single binary. It can even act as a drop-in replacement for Plausible and use the same scripts. Thereâ€™s an example of a live dashboard. GitHubÂ repo.

Geofrey Ernest

ğŸ”ŠÂ go-taglib: Read/Write Audio Metadata Tags â€” Read and write metadata tags for audio files (like MP3, FLAC, and OGG) including support for multi-valued tags. Portable with no external runtime dependencies (it embeds a WASM version of the C++-based taglib). (Note: LGPLÂ licensed.)

Senan Kelly

WorkOS: Sell to Enterprises with a Few Lines of Code â€” The modern identity platform for B2B SaaS, offering flexible, easy-to-use APIs to integrate SSO, SCIM, and FGA in minutes instead ofÂ months.

WorkOS sponsor

Rill 0.6: A Composable Concurrency Toolkit for Go â€” A collection of functions for streaming, parallel processing, and pipeline construction â€“ all aiming to make it â€œeasier to build concurrent programs from simple, reusableÂ parts.â€

Viktor Nikolaiev

ğŸª¨Â Pebble: RocksDB/LevelDB Inspired Key-Value Database in Go â€” A key-value store focused on performance that uses RockDBâ€™s file format but adds a few extra features that CockroachDB needs. Itâ€™s used at scale within CockroachDB and is considered stable and productionÂ ready.

CockroachDB

ğŸ•¸ï¸Â Katana: A Web Crawling and Spidering Framework â€” A flexible Go-powered Web crawling tool (which can also be used as a library from Go) that can work in both headless and non-headless modes and has lots of customizableÂ features.

ProjectDiscovery

shortuuid 4.2: Generate Concise, Unambiguous and URL-Safe UniqueÂ IDs â€” These arenâ€™t standardized UUIDs, but for when you want short, non-sequential user-facing IDs (e.g. KwSysDpxcBU9FNhGkn2dCf).

Peter Lithammer

Quill 0.5: Sign Mac Binaries from Any Platform â€” Give it a signing private key and certificate from Apple, Quill does the rest to sign and notarize macOSÂ binaries.

Anchore, Inc.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

How Authorization fits into the Architecture of Secure AI RAG stacks? Watch AuthZed CEO Jacob Moshenko addressing this topic, and more with TheÂ Cube.

ğŸª Hookdeck: A serverless queue to reliably send, receive, transform, filter, and route events across your event-drivenÂ apps.

  • BadgerDB 4.5 â€“ Embeddable, fast pure-Go key-valueÂ DB.

  • SFTPGo 2.6.4 â€“ Full featured SFTPÂ server.Â (Docs.)

  • Go OpenAI 1.36 â€“ An OpenAI API wrapperÂ library.

  • go-github v67.0 â€“ GitHub v3 API clientÂ library.

  • Goyave 5.5 â€“ Enterprise REST APIÂ framework.

#â€‹535 â€” December 10, 2024

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

ğŸ•’Â Coming in Go 1.24: An Experiment for Time and ConcurrencyÂ Testing â€” A look at another feature coming to Go 1.24 early next year. This time itâ€™s the experimental testing/synctest package which opens up some added opportunities for testing code involving time or concurrency: â€œIt seems that testing/synctest will significantly improve testing code that involves time or concurrency. At work, Iâ€™ve already tried it on some flaky tests like the ones above and itâ€™sÂ helped.â€

Dan Peterson

What's Missing from Go's Generics? â€” Follow-up to an article we recently linked that posited that Goâ€™s generics are â€˜incompleteâ€™ which spurred some lively discussion. Here, Nick responds to that discussion with specific features and how Go may or may not benefit from theirÂ inclusion.

Nick Tobey (DoltHub)

Master the Basics of Go â€” Join Maximiliano Firtman for this detailed video course covering the fundamentals of all things Go. You'll gain a thorough understanding of structures, goroutines, channels, async API calls, and much muchÂ more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

IN BRIEF:

  • Mostly noteworthy for its nice sounding version number, Go 1.23.4 has been released.

  • ğŸ¤– An interesting result in Cloudflare's 2024 year in review: Go has overtaken Node.js as the most common language they see being used to power 'API clients'/automatedÂ requests.

  • Microsoft has released new versions of its custom Go builds covering Go 1.23.4 and 1.22.10. (You'd use these for FIPS compliance in the MS ecosystem.)

  • ğŸ¤– If you're into working with LLMs and AI from Go, /r/LLMGophers is a new sub-Reddit you might want to helpÂ populate.

  • Simon Willison tries to figure out what the absolute simplest possible Hugo-powered site wouldÂ be.

Templ vs Gomponents vs html/template â€” A comparison of three view related libraries for Go, including old favorite html/template (which, perhaps unfairly, gets a one starÂ rating).

Ewen Quimercâ€™h

ğŸ“„ Building BLE Applications with BleuIO and Go â€“ BLE meaning Bluetooth Low Energy, in this case. They have a device theyâ€™re trying to sell, but itâ€™s interesting to get a basic look at theÂ idea. BleuIO

ğŸ“„ Data Structures as Jigs for Programmers (Go Edition) Daniel Lemire

ğŸ“„ Mitigating SSRF Vulnerabilities in Go Liran Tal (Snyk)

ğŸ“„ Disable Slog Messages in Go Tests Ben E. C. Boyter

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Soft Serve 0.8: A Self-Hostable Go-Powered Git Server â€” Another handy project from the folks at Charm. Soft Serve is a self-hostable Git server that offers up a nice terminal UI (TUI) over SSH, has various access control features for collaborative use cases, and even supports GitÂ LFS.

Charm

âš™ï¸Â Orchestrion: Compile-Time Auto-Instrumentation for Go â€” Instrumenting code is tedious and inconsistent when done manually, but automating it is difficult. Enter Orchestrion, which injects instrumentation at compile-time and supports many third-party libraries so you can instrument your code, create tracers, etc. without changing the devÂ process.

Datadog Team

Zero Ops Apache Kafka Replication and Data Mirroring â€” Moving to WarpStream to reduce your Kafka costs by 80+% and simplify ops is easy with 1:1 replication provided byÂ Orbit.

WarpStream sponsor

go-wasm-http-server 2.0: Embed Go HTTP Handlers in a Service Worker â€” Embed your Go HTTP handlers in a Service Worker using WebAssembly and emulate an HTTP server browser-side. Some of the examples might give you someÂ inspiration.

Nicolas Lepage

Goverter: A Type-Safe Go Converter Generator â€” Generate type-safe converters by writing signatures of the type conversions and then Goverter will write the code you need to make it happen. GitHubÂ repo.

Jannis Mattheis

Echo: Extensible, Minimalist Go Web Framework â€” Though itâ€™s not too minimal, offering HTTP routing, automatic TLS, data binding, templating, middleware, and different ways to render data out of the box. v4.13.0 removes the JWT middleware from Echo core due to security issues. GitHubÂ repo.

LabStack LLC

GTML: Make Writing HTML in Go a Breeze â€” This package touts itself with â€œThink of it like JSX for Go,â€ allowing you to take an HTML-like syntax and generate a StringBuilder that renders it in GoÂ code.

Phillip England

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

How Authorization fits into the Architecture of Secure AI RAG stacks? Watch AuthZed CEO Jacob Moshenko addressing this topic, and more with TheÂ Cube.

ğŸ“¬ Hookdeck: A serverless queue to reliably send, receive, transform, filter, and route events across your event-drivenÂ apps.

ğŸ‘‹ Tired of failures and outages? Let Temporal keep your code running flawlessly. Start on Temporal Cloud with $1,000 in freeÂ credits.

gARM: An ARM64 Compiler for Go â€” The author thinks we can do better than Goâ€™s assembly approach for high performance ARM64 use cases, so has set out to make his own approach. It's early days, however.

Sven Woldt

  • golang-set 2.7 â€“ Robust generic setÂ type. Now supports proper JSON marshalling/unmarshalling withoutÂ workarounds.

  • FastHTTP 1.58 â€“ Performance-oriented alternative to net/http for specificÂ scenarios.

  • ğŸ¤– go-pot 1.0 â€“ A Go 'HTTP tarpit' designed to 'maximize botÂ misery.'

  • Mockery 2.50 â€“ Generate mocks forÂ interfaces.

  • webdav 5.5 â€“ Standalone WebDAVÂ server.
